newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish court adjourns Islamist mayor case.
newsitem.headline: Turkish court adjourns Islamist mayor case.

text.p: A Turkish court on Thursday adjourned the trial of a former mayor from Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's Welfare Party on charges of serious public order offences for organising an Islamist, anti-Israeli protest.
"Given the evidence, the court has decided to keep the defendants in custody. The next hearing will take place on June 6," Judge Turgut Okyay told the court.

Mayor Bekir Yildiz and five others are in custody because of their role in a "Jerusalem Night" rally in January in Ankara's Sincan district, which enraged secularists who regarded the protest as a call for the implementation of Islamic sharia law.
The rest of the 11 people on trial were released last month but the charges against them remain the same. The mayor faces three to five years in jail.
Yildiz and Iranian ambassador Ali Reza Bagheri spoke on a stage draped with a banner of the late leader of the militant Palestinian group Islamic Jihad, Fathi Shqaqi.

Iran and much of the Arab world have expressed unease at Turkey's growing defence ties with the Jewish state. A deal signed last year has allowed Israeli air force jets to train in the ample air space of Turkey, a Moslem but secular country.
Tanks toured Sincan several days after the Jerusalem protest in an apparent warning to Islamists from the secular army.
Erbakan, under pressure from the powerful military, has toned down his colourful rhetoric since becoming Turkey's first Islamist prime minister in June last year.
